resources.string: The accumulated interest paid to date
This is the net balance for the year: f(x)=income - outlay
This value is the accumulating after tax cash flow from year to year
This is the summation of the present values of after tax cash flows to date
Amount received from sale of house, minus broker fees and inflation-adjusted miscellaneous fees
This is the after tax equity reversion in present value dollars
This is the amount the broker receives at the time when you sell the investment, based on the percentage set
The value of the building itself, not the total estate (which includes land)
This is the cap rate based on the original purchase value of the investment. The equation is yearly Net Operating Income (NOI) / purchase value
This is the cap rate based on the current estimated value of the investment. The equation is yearly Net Operating Income (NOI) / current value

costs incurred at the time of purchase of investment, such as surveyor fees, home inspection, title insurance, termite bond, and any other miscellaneous fees *other* than the amount owed to the broker at the time of purchase
The amount of principal left to pay off on the loan
The amount of money given by the investor towards the purchase price of the investment
Number of extra years to calculate past the mortgage end
The amount of money necessary to bring the investment up to repair for the purposes of liquidating the investment
The yearly rate of inflation. This is the rate at which currency loses value per year.

This is the expected yearly amount to put aside for general expenses necessary to keep the investment in good repair without losing value. Examples may include having to repair the HVAC, paying for lawn care, retaining a management company or handyman, or other general yearly expenses.
This is the initial yearly cost of home insurance
These fees are yearly assessments on property owners for such things as environment fees, sewer fees, or other fees which are frequently included in the yearly property tax bill

The percentage rate that the investment amount is taxed. The reason this is called ""marginal" tax rate is because it is assumed that you have other income and this is on top of that. So, due to the different tax brackets, the best way to determine your tax rate is to find what is the top bracket you are currently in for your other income, and then apply that to the rental income on this property. Note that this value does not apply to the equity reversion (investment sale). In that case the rate is the capital gains rate, which as of 2012 is 15%

The modified internal rate of return is an equation to determine the comparative attractiveness of an investment, to rank alternative investments of equal size. Note that the equal size of investments is important. If the projects are of unequal size, it help to review the value of the net present value to get a more fair comparison.\n\nThe equation for MIRR is as follows: for any number n of cash flows, MIRR = nth root of the Future value of positive cash flows using the reinvestment rate divided by the Present value of negative cash flows at the finance rate, all minus 1
The monthly mortgage payment. This is calculated by the following formula: AMT_BORROWED * ( (INT_RATE / 12) / (1 - (1 / (1 + INT_RATE)^(YEARS * 12) ) )

The monthly rent for this year. Assumption: The amount of rent charged goes up once every twelve months starting from the house purchase date. Rent increases per the yearly real estate appreciation rate.

The net present value is the sum of the present values for each year\'s final balance. In this application, this means it is the first payment (down payment, fix-up costs, and general purchase expenses) plus the yearly after tax cash flows (all in present value by the required rate of return as a discount rate) and finally the present value of the after-tax equity reversion (the sale of the purchase)
number of compounding periods for this investment. For most typical mortgages, such as 15 or 30-year fixed mortgages, this means monthly compounding, so 180 or 360 months respectively

This amount is what the lender charges extra in addition to the mortgage payment for their insurance against default. It is typically assessed when the down payment is less than 20% of the loan. That is how this application handles it.
The expected value of the investment at the time of sale, assuming the value increases at the rate set by the real estate appreciation rate
This is the yearly property tax amount assessed on the investment

This is the anticipated rate of monthly appreciation of the investment. In this application, the future value of the investment is determined by using this rate plus one to the monthly compounding period desired

This is the minimum rate of return desired by the investor. It is an important rate as it determines the discount rate for the net present value equation. This rate should be set to the cost of capital, since you want investments to at least bring in more than it costs you to take out a loan for an investment (or else you would gain no profit).
This rate is assessed on the anticipated investment value at the time of sale, to pay for the broker
These are the general expenses expected at the time of selling the investment, modified using the future value equation with the inflation rate.
The street address of the investment
This is the amount of income which is taxable. Namely, the yearly interest payments are subtracted from the income.
Taxes taken at the sale of the investment. This is currently 15% (all capital gains are 15%) in 2012
The value of the entire estate; building, land, and all
This is the estimated average yearly loss due to either of the following: tenants failing to pay their rent, or not having someone in the unit.
All income - all expenses, before tax

Estimated yearly expenses for things such as management costs, lawn care (if the contract requires it), miscellaneous building repair, and so on. Note that it also includes saving up for big ticket items such as replacing the roof or HVAC. So, for example, you may save an extra $30 per month each year towards the future roof replacement.
The yearly general insurance rate. Note that rental property insurance rates are typically higher than normal homeowner rates. Check with your insurance agent.

This is the income gained each year through the rent. This application assumes that the rate you charge will increase once a year at the rate of real estate appreciation. the equation for next year\'s rent is: this_year_monthly_rent * (1 + real_estate_appreciation_rate / 12)
The amount of interest paid this year in the mortgage payments. This application assumes a standard loan amortization
The interest rate charged by the lender for the loan.
The future value yearly municipal fees

All expenses for the year except debt service (mortgage payment). This includes property tax, management fees, insurance premiums, maintenance costs, utility fees, or other expenses made in the operation of the investment property. Assumption: The yearly general expenses increase at the rate of yearly inflation. They increase at this rate once a year.
The income for the year (rent) minus vacancy and credit losses, minus yearly operating expenses
All expenses for the year - debt service, home insurance, property tax, municipal fees, general expenses (maintenance), and private mortgage insurance

The amount paid this year in private mortgage insurance. The monthly amount is set in the loan edit dialog. If the amount outstanding on the loan is more than 80% of the total value, the monthly private mortgage insurance amount will be charged each month until it reaches 80%
The amount of principal paid in the mortgage payments for this year

The amount of property tax paid this year. This application calculates each year\'s property tax by a future value equation using real estate appreciation as the rate of compounding. Assumption: this tax is paid once a year.
Tax on the portion of income which is at the marginal tax rate, or in other words, the taxable income times the marginal tax rate. Assumption: This tax is paid once a year.
Use GPS to set current location
General comments related to the property

Cost to fix up the property to a rentable state as a one-time dollar amount. Assumption: the fix-up costs (costs which are expended near the time of purchase) commensurately increase the total value of the investment. This means that if you buy a $250k investment and spend $50k on improvements (fix-up) the total value is now $300k.

Enter the total purchase value for the investment. This application will then make assumptions of the other numbers and provide an analysis. You can then modify the default values as necessary for a more precise result

REAP has the following features: 
* calculate important real estate appraisal values 
* dynamically modify values to suit 
* ease of use 
* robust results
Press and hold on an entry to delete

The total purchase value of the investment. values are calculated using the following formulas: 
loan interest rate = 5.5% 
private mortgage insurance is $100 / month 
down payment = 20% * totalValue 
closing costs = $1000 
marginal tax rate is 25% 
building value = 80% * totalValue 
property tax = 1% * totalValue 
local municipal fees = 0 
general sale expenses = $2000 
selling broker rate is 6% 
inflation rate is 3% 
real estate appreciation rate is 4% 
rent = 0.5% * totalValue (or none if rental not checked) 
home insurance = $1000 / year 
vacancy rate is 3% 
fix-up costs are $0 
yearly general expenses is $1000 
required rate of return is 5.5%

Real Estate Analysis Processor
